Title.evidence: The purpose of this study was to compare results from a randomized clinical trial (RCT)

Trial_Design.evidence: This is a concise followup of a previously reported RCT.

Participants.evidence: robot-assisted primary THA was performed on 75 hips (69 patients), and a hand-rasping technique was used on 71 hips (61 patients).

Intervention.evidence: robot-assisted primary THA was performed on 75 hips (69 patients), and a hand-rasping technique was used on 71 hips (61 patients).

Objective.evidence: The purpose of this study was to compare results from a randomized clinical trial (RCT)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary study endpoint was the JOA score, which is scored from 0 to 100, with higher scores representing better function and less pain.

Blinding.evidence: assessed using the four-grade Brooker scale by individuals other than the operating surgeon.

Number_Randomised.evidence: robot-assisted primary THA was performed on 75 hips (69 patients), and a hand-rasping technique was used on 71 hips (61 patients).

Number_Analysed.evidence: 115 of 130 (88%) of patients initially randomized were available for followup at a minimum of 10 years

Result_Outcome.evidence: At a minimum of 10 years postoperatively, there were no differences between patients treated with robot-assisted surgery or hand rasping in JOA scores (97 ± 5 versus 96 ± 7, mean difference 1.4; p = 0.159).

Harms.evidence: No stems in either group developed aseptic loosening, and there were no revisions in either group.
